Quantum theory is often described as a theory of linear operators on vector spaces. However, this description is incomplete because it does not capture the essential role played by the inner product in quantum theory. In this paper, we provide a categorical description of quantum theory that is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This description is based on a notion of morphism between categories of Hilbert spaces and operators, which we call “continuous linear maps.” We show that this notion of morphism is equivalent to the notion of quantum operation. This result provides a mathematical foundation for the operational interpretation of quantum theory. It also suggests that the theory of quantum operations is a natural generalization of the theory of linear operators on vector spaces. Finally, we show that the theory of quantum operations is equivalent to a certain class of quantum many-body states. This equivalence provides a new perspective on the problem of defining a mathematical structure that underlies quantum theory.

Our results show that myxozoans are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, and that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals. In addition, we find that myxozoans have lost many genes involved in development and cell differentiation, and that they have lost the ability to form a multicellular body. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. In the male reproductive system, sperm cells are quiescent in the absence of Zn2+, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+ environment of the female reproductive tract. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. The world’s food production systems are vulnerable to climate change. In this study, we quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields and production in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for urgent investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition for seven species of large herbivores in a semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between species, even when they were matched in body size and proportional grass consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that large herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large herbivore populations.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program. Our results suggest that the CARES Act should be complemented by grants to help small businesses through this crisis.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris load on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris larger than 1 mm by the ocean interior. This sink is likely to be a major process in the global fate of floating plastic debris.

The cosmic ray exposure ages of presolar grains are a key parameter for understanding the history of the solar system. We determined ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for understanding the history of the solar system. They also provide constraints for the formation of the solar system.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother during pregnancy is a defining characteristic of the evolution of all mammals. This ability is thought to be limited by the mother’s metabolic capacity, and thus, the increase in reproductive output associated with domestication and allomaternal care is difficult to explain. Here, we show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the mother’s metabolic capacity, rather than an increase in the number of litters or the number of offspring per litter. This result suggests that the increase in reproductive output associated with domestication and allomaternal care is due to an increase in the mother’s metabolic capacity, rather than an increase in the number of litters or the number of offspring per litter. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This is the first study to show that VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This finding opens the way for further studies in this model and in patients. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, both for public health and for researchers. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 signals, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These signals are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The COVIDcast API is available for free to the public, and we hope that it will be useful to researchers, policymakers, and the general public.

Potassium channels are a large family of proteins that are involved in a variety of physiological processes. They are responsible for the regulation of the electrical properties of the cell membrane and, therefore, play a crucial role in the functioning of the nervous system and the heart. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the ion permeation. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a critical role in health and disease. The role of the anaerobic gut fungi in this ecosystem is not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic gut fungi. These results provide a foundation for further investigation of the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to produce bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism

The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, which is based on the physical model of the prescribed response and the material properties of the constituent materials. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, which is based on the digital model of the prescribed response. The structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The proposed approach can also be extended to the design of other complex systems, such as fluids and granular materials. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in the human body. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This is achieved by reduced expression of the adult hemoglobin genes beta and delta and increased gamma-globin expression. IGF2BP1 also mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for the expression of the fetal hemoglobin gene alpha. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of ferroptosis and suggest a strategy for the treatment of cancer patients with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Hypertension is the leading risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs). However, the long-term use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ sensor system in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is associated with vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. However, caution is warranted in the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and was the first plan to use the concept of ecosystem management. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test the influence of this policy on biodiversity. Our results show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the opposite occurred for older-forest–associated species. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The evolution of Lake Malawi, East Africa, is a key process in the development of the world’s largest tropical lake and one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the lake’s hydroclimate and lake-level variability. The record shows dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in the lake and its ecosystem. The record also shows evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. The shift in lake level variability at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition is consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The record also shows that the lake was often overfilled, indicating a wetter climate, but these highstands were interrupted by prolonged intervals of extreme drought.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the function of CTLA-4 is not limited to the early development of autoimmunity, but also in the maintenance of tolerance.

We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes for 521 species, including 154 genomes or transcriptomes. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. We propose that PCWDEs enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the evolution of the size of the population than for the evolution of the performance of the artifacts.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is protective whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. APOE is also highly associated with astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system that is highly phagocytic. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The inner core is a solid region with a radius of about 2,350 km, which is the deepest part of the Earth. It is a key part of the Earth that has been the subject of many studies. However, there is a contradiction between the results of some studies and the current understanding of the inner core. This contradiction is referred to as the inner core nucleation paradox. In this paper, we propose a solution to this paradox. We show that the bcc phase of iron has a higher nucleation rate than does the hcp phase under inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the inner core. They also provide a new way to understand the formation of the Earth. They are expected to be useful for the study of the inner core and the Earth.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain reactivity to DA stimulation is a potential target for the treatment of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural network language models can predict neural and behavioral responses to spoken sentences in the human brain. This suggests that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms. These results provide a computational framework for understanding the neural and behavioral mechanisms of language comprehension, and may help to explain the evolution of language in humans and other animals.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. In this paper, we show that this instability is due to the use of algorithms that are not stable. We introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENET), which is both stable and fast. We prove that FIRENET is stable and show that only O(|log (ϵ)|)) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. We also prove that there are problems where no algorithm can compute a stable neural network with a given accuracy. These results provide a classification theory of the conditions under which stable neural networks can be computed by algorithms. We believe that this theory will be useful in the development of stable DL algorithms.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. The two genomes are highly similar, and we discuss the implications of these findings for the evolution of the leprosy pathogens.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the keystones of quantum information science and statistical physics. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics of a quantum system can be completely understood in the space–time scaling limit, without making any assumption on the system’s Hamiltonian. This is a major step forward in the study of the entanglement dynamics, which is a key open problem in quantum physics.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria is well established, but its function in the cell as a whole is less clear. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that mediate many cellular processes. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled, and the process of disassembly is regulated by a family of proteins. We show that these proteins can exert a mechanical torque on the filaments, which enhances the disassembly of the filaments. This mechanism is important for the disassembly of highly connected filaments, such as those in the cortex of cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study provides evidence that fructose ingestion may be associated with greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing, which may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related metabolic diseases.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken, and it is the only island in the world where the Bantu language family is spoken. The island is also a hotspot of endemism, with 40% of its plant species being unique to Madagascar. The island is also a unique case in terms of its human history, with a long-standing debate about the settlement history of the island. We present a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we find that Madagascar was settled by a Bantu population and a population of Austronesian origin. The settlement history of Madagascar is also shown to be sex biased, with a recent population growth and a recent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that Madagascar is a genetic hotspot, with a strong influence of geography on the genetic diversity. These results provide a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar. They also provide a better understanding of the genetic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity.

We show that the amount of positive and negative content in a person’s Facebook News Feed influences that person’s own emotional state. These results suggest that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks and the spread of emotions in society. It also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a common feature of the transcriptome. However, the functional consequences of these modifications are not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA codons can have a modest impact on translation. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can have subtle effects on translation and may contribute to the regulation of gene expression. Our work provides insight into the functional consequences of mRNA modifications and may have implications for the development of mRNA-based therapeutics. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships, and that this association is independent of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining positive outcomes at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in biology, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. We use a model of the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is constrained by the energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinoviruses are the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of these viruses to replicate more efficiently at cool nasal cavity temperatures than at core body temperature has important implications for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here we show that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at cool nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth and may help to inform the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability to sense the environment is a fundamental property of all organisms. In bacteria, this process is often mediated by flagella, which are used for motility and sensing. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its flagella to sense the environment. This mechanochemical process is mediated by the type IV pili, a major surface adhesin, and results in the activation of a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates the production of virulence factors. This finding provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria use their flagella to sense the environment and highlights the importance of the interplay between motility and sensing in bacterial behavior. This work also provides a new paradigm for understanding the role of flagella in bacterial sensing. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of sensing systems in bacteria and the role of flagella in sensing in bacterial motility. They also have implications for the development of antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is of great importance for the future of our planet. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides is associated with a substantial risk for the biological integrity of global water resources. This risk is high even in countries with stringent environmental regulations. The results of this study suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the emergence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes it, has been one of the most significant events of the 21st century. The virus has spread to all corners of the globe, and the dynamics of its spread are still not fully understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is endemic to North America. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlights the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future, but hydropower is still the leading source of renewable energy. This paper studies the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ plaque deposits and cell death. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of producing potent immune factors, and that these are released into the extracellular environment. We demonstrate that these neuron-derived cytokines correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. We also show that a neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede insoluble Aβ plaque and tau tangle formation within the human brain. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. These findings may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. It is a main source of protein for more than one billion people worldwide. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the ancient world. Our results suggest that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry was preceded by at least a century by the adoption in the Southern Levant. This gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in molecular biology. The folding of a single protein is a complex process that involves many steps and many intermediates. The folding of a large protein is even more complex, because it involves many steps and many intermediates. Here we describe the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, and show that it has a distinct native-like intermediate in a distinct step of the folding process. This intermediate is a major obstacle to the folding of the protein, and the folding of the protein is a major obstacle to the understanding of protein folding.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are required for the rapid degradation of the transcripts. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the caps is not the one that is inactivated by the stress conditions that enable accumulation of the caps, but rather a different enzyme that recognizes capped 5′ termini in a manner distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. This enzyme, which we name RNA pyrophosphohydrolase, is able to deprotect capped 5′ termini at a much higher rate than other phosphorylated termini, and it is required for the rapid degradation of capped transcripts. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality rates. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the immunosuppression that is a major cause of sepsis-associated morbidity and mortality. Here, we show that arginine, an essential amino acid, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore the immune system during sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This strategy could be used as a preventive measure to reduce the risk of sepsis-associated morbidity and mortality. Furthermore, it could also be used as a therapeutic measure to improve the outcome of sepsis patients. These results could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to a state of constant activity. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including sandpiles, neural networks, and fracture processes. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and the bandgap can be tuned by strain. We also show that diamond can be used as a mechanical switch. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides against plant fungal pathogens is not well understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens. We also report the mode of action of this peptide against plant fungal pathogens. Our work provides insights into the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides against plant fungal pathogens. This work also paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely to be a site of molecular continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The A1 domain in VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα), in a reaction triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF A1 and GPIbα to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains pathophysiology and is applicable to other systems. The results are important for understanding the role of force in the regulation of VWF and other proteins. They also provide a general approach for understanding the effects of force on proteins. The approach may be applicable to other systems.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that is intimately involved in health and disease. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, which is available to the scientific community at https://www.humanvirome.org/. We find that the human virome is associated with disease, and that the association is stronger for some viruses than for others. These results provide a foundation for future studies of the role of viruses in health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI. The results provide substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The HSRL is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to be widely used in the future.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the evolution of life on the planet. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is also important for understanding the evolution of the atmosphere, which is a key component of the Earth system. This study provides a new perspective on the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels can exhibit slow C-type inactivation/recovery and that the rates of C-type inactivation/recovery are inversely correlated with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channels. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide and is a major cause of death and disability. The Plasmodium parasite invades the red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle and cause disease. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) in this process is unknown. Here, we show that EBA175 binding to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the red cell and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. These changes in the RBC are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and may lead to the development of new antimalarial therapies. (Show more)

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of ambient humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza-associated morbidity and mortality. These findings may help to develop strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s response to words varies with each successive word in a sentence, but suddenly increases when words can be merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with a neural implementation of a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system that is shared by humans and other species.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in the development of the embryo and the regulation of cell fate in adult tissues. Axin is a large protein that is composed of two functionally distinct domains, a kinase domain and a scaffolding domain. The scaffolding domain is responsible for the interaction with β-catenin, which is the main downstream effector of the Wnt signaling pathway. In this study, we show that the scaffolding domain of Axin1 and Axin2 are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the Wnt signaling pathway. This differential regulation may be used to control the activity of the Wnt signaling pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. Here we show that this effect is mediated by dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra, and that this circuit is necessary for the induction of eating. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is mediated by LH neurons that synapse onto neurons in the locus coeruleus and the more caudal part of the ventral tegmental area. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a key goal for sustainable food production. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the nitrogenase enzyme, which fixes atmospheric nitrogen, is turned on only when the plant is present and the bacteria are in contact. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to deliver nitrogen to cereal crops, which are the most important food crops in the world. It could also be applied to other crops, such as legumes, which are able to fix nitrogen in the soil but are unable to do so in the presence of cereal crops. This work represents a significant step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in agriculture. (Show more)

The Amazon is losing forest cover at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are a critical tool for monitoring and mitigating deforestation, but they are rarely used to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses remote-sensed deforestation alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests in response to alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s small sample size and the difficulty of attributing deforestation to the program. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and aerosols are often considered separately. We show that the two are strongly coupled, and that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. While vaccines are the most effective way to control the pandemic, the current vaccines are expensive and may not be accessible to all. We report a recombinant protein that can be expressed in large quantities in bacteria, and can be used to construct a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine. This protein can be used to develop vaccines that are affordable and accessible to all.

The role of the ALK/ALKALS receptor tyrosine kinases in development is well established. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALS can activate ALK/ALKALS in vivo. This is the first demonstration of ligand–receptor activation in vivo for this family of receptors. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKALS in neural crest development. This is of importance for understanding the role of ALK/ALKALS in human cancer.

The emergence of plague, the deadliest pathogen in human history, is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during a critical period of development. Our results suggest that the plague pathogen was not a single lineage but rather a population that persisted over millennia without significant diversification. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a new perspective on the history of plague and its relationship to its host. It also provides a resource for future studies of the history of plague and its vectors. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question for the future of agriculture and the global carbon cycle. In this study, we show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated organic carbon in a long-term field experiment. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and rotational grazing of pastures. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon in agricultural landscapes and provide a framework for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems. This work also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments in understanding the effects of management on soil processes and SOC storage. This study is a contribution to the broader effort to understand the role of grasslands in the global carbon cycle and the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize zoonotic viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to estimate the zoonotic spillover potential of wildlife viruses. Using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the risk of 887 wildlife viruses. The top 12 were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a valuable resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. Here, we identify a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin, as the red pigment in the blood-red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus. We also identify the same alkaloid in the nectar of hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae, providing evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a molecular basis for the evolution of a visually attractive trait in plants and may have implications for the study of convergent evolution in vertebrates. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood, despite the fact that it is a period of great cultural and social change. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of the men is mostly of northern and central European origin, while the women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period and suggest that complex demographic processes may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how MERS-CoV spreads to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. These findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for preventing future MERS outbreaks. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including dengue virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and chikungunya virus. Our findings highlight the importance of mNGS as a pathogen surveillance tool in resource-scarce settings and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. These findings also highlight the importance of early detection of emerging pathogens, such as chikungunya virus, to inform public health response. These findings are important for the development of a global surveillance network to better understand the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. This will enable more rapid and effective public health response to emerging epidemics. (PsycINFO Database Record

The lagging strand of the double helix is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. This process is essential for the synthesis of the genome and is critical for the survival of the organism. However, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the replication of the lagging strand. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of PCNA in the regulation of DNA replication. This study is of general interest to the scientific community and will be of particular interest to those working on the structure and function of DNA polymerases and their associated proteins.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the RNA world hypothesis, life began with the evolution of RNA molecules that could replicate and carry out other functions. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules, and, in the process, we demonstrate that this polymerase can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. These results provide a significant step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory. They also provide a foundation for the study of the origin of life, because they demonstrate that the replication of RNA can be accomplished in the absence of proteins.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies, but it is difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three classical theories of urban change are supported by our data: (i) the role of human capital in neighborhood improvement, (ii) the role of initial appearance in neighborhood improvement, and (iii) the role of physical proximity to other attractive neighborhoods in neighborhood improvement. Our results provide a new way to study urban change and a new way to study the physical geography of cities. They also provide a new way to study the role of physical geography in the distribution of economic opportunity.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical patients is difficult. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper homeostasis is essential for the growth and survival of fungi, and the mechanisms by which fungi regulate copper content are not well understood. Here we demonstrate that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and impacts cellular copper content. We also show that xanthocillin-derived isocyanide products have antimicrobial properties and inhibit the activity of the fungal laccases, which are important mediators of oxidative stress in fungal infections. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings may have implications for the understanding of fungal infections and the development of antifungal therapies. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is not stable at the present day temperature of the Red Planet. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and is derived from a silicic volcanic source. The amorphous material is precipitated from multiple aqueous solutions, some of which are acidic. The diagenesis of the amorphous material is complex and is likely to have involved multiple episodes of mixing of different fluids.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that trees are adapting to these changes by changing their frost resistance strategies. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by two distinct mechanisms. First, Th17 cells can directly transition to Th1-like cells, which are required for the development of colitis. Second, Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results provide insight into the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease and suggest that targeting both of these mechanisms may be a useful strategy for the treatment of this disease. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in many genes, but the underlying mechanisms are not known. Here we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the disease and identify new therapies. This method will also enable the rapid production of large numbers of motor neurons for disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This will greatly accelerate ALS research and lead to the development of new therapies. This method will also be applicable to other diseases that cause motor neuron degeneration.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the colonization of the pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. However, the mechanisms by which the pathogen influences the tick microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to produce antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the tick gut microbiota. We demonstrate that iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan pentapeptide chain, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in the history of tetrapods. The study of the early evolution of the avian body plan is therefore critical for understanding the origin of the modern bird body plan. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group and the evolution of the avian body plan.

The climate system is a coupled system, and the response of one part of the system to a forcing can affect the response of another part. In the case of water vapor, the tropics are the main source of water vapor for the stratosphere, but the tropics are also the region where the largest increases in greenhouse gases are occurring. This means that the tropics are the region where the largest increases in water vapor are occurring, and that these increases will affect the climate of the whole planet.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, which are often used to camouflage the animals in their natural environment. However, some animals, such as frogs, are green, which is not very well camouflaged in the green foliage. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. In this study, we found that the green color of frogs is due to the presence of a biliverdin-binding protein, which is most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin. This is the first functional diversification of a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most abundant group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and a new function for a member of the serpin family. This study also provides a new tool for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates. Finally, it may also have implications for the evolution of color in other organisms.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of breast cancer, and are thought to be responsible for the recurrence of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG is methylated at a specific residue in its 3′-UTR, which is demethylated by ALKBH5. Thus, ALKBH5 is a mediator of the effects of hypoxia on breast cancer stem cells. This study provides a mechanism for the effects of hypoxia on breast cancer stem cells, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The use of fetal calf or sheep skin for parchment is a longstanding controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We analyzed 465 samples from 72 pocket Bibles and 293 additional samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be applied to other historical documents to help identify the animal origin of parchment. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction is the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is controversial, but the timing of the extinction is well constrained by the presence of volcanic ash deposits at the Permian-Triassic boundary. Here we present a new age model for the extinction, based on U-Pb dating of zircon from five ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. They also provide a new benchmark for evaluating the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction and its aftermath. (Contains figures and tables.) more

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in the regulation of various biological processes. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and suggests that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development and the focus of much research on the mechanisms of viral entry. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of viral entry and may inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof is based on a new method that combines techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We also show that, under the same assumptions, the set of equilibria is nonempty. This extends the result of Fudenberg and Levine [D. Fudenberg and D. P. Levine, Ann. Econ. Pol. 1, 1 (2000)] to repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are fundamental to the understanding of the chemical world. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure. Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity and carbon emissions, and we show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes. This is important for understanding the future trajectory of the climate system and the role of terrestrial ecosystems in mitigating climate change.

The symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a classic example of a mutualism in which the host provides a specific glycan to the symbiont, which in turn provides a benefit to the host. We show here that the glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is active, and that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont to enhance the pH of the symbiotic crypts, which in turn enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. This study provides a mechanistic link between the provision of a glycan by the host and the luminescence of the symbiont. This glycan-provisioned mutualism may be a common feature of symbioses in which the host provides a specific nutrient to its symbiont. Such a strategy may be important for the stability of the mutualism. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify the latent patterns that describe the data. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as sequences of patterns. We model the generative process of a document as a sequence of latent topics, each of which is associated with a distribution over words. We also model the generative process of a word as a sequence of latent topics, each of which is associated with a distribution over words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model latent patterns in text data. It can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as sequences of topics. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics and compare the gender bias of topics to the gender bias of the data.
