The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and on the role of climate in the spread of this disease. Asteroids are a common component of the Northeast Pacific Coast ecosystem. In recent years, a disease has been observed that has led to the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the tissues. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the starfish itself. The virus has been present in the ecosystem for at least 72 y. This study provides evidence that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. The identification of targets for the treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. Here, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, we show that the antibody can be used to target IL-1 signaling, which is important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, the antibody is capable of achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important insights into the treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian and Bantu populations are present. This study provides a detailed picture of the genetic history of Madagascar, which is a key step to understand the origin of the Malagasy people and their cultural diversity.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings provide insight into the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria. They also demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete with each other. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics.

Crop expert surveys are a key source of information on crop status, but are often ignored in favor of more sophisticated models. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by the US Department of Agriculture, is a rich source of information that can be used to monitor crop status and predict yields. We show that the survey data can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We also show that the survey data are stable over time, and can be used to monitor the status of crops in different regions of the country. Finally, we show that the survey data can be used to monitor crop conditions and predict yields earlier and more accurately than official forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert surveys in agricultural monitoring.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the order in which information is presented. This makes it suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, and use this data set to investigate the temperature response of soil respiration. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration rates increase with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major evolutionary event in the history of life, and the molecular signature of this process is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. Our model is based on the assumption that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle is accompanied by a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. We show that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are modulated by macrostructural and microstructural changes in the genome, and that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are modulated by macrostructural and microstructural changes in the genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. This process is likely to have had a major impact on the evolution of the plastid genome. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the past century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought by a factor of five to six. This is a significant contribution to the risk of drought in SSA, which is highly sensitive to anthropogenic climate change. The results highlight the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to reduce the risk of drought in SSA.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the discovery of quasicrystals in the laboratory, and the synthesis of new quasicrystal-forming systems, has been slow. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in the material that was formed at the instant of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test” of 16 July 1945. This discovery provides a link between the laboratory synthesis of quasicrystals and the history of the 20th century.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. Here we show that the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring is catalyzed by a protein that we term BciE, encoded by a gene conserved in alphaproteobacteria. This is the first example of a protein that is required for the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in oxygenic phototrophs.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS). However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation in autoimmune diseases remain largely unknown. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology, and we propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroinflammation in autoimmune diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. We also find that the probability of drought has increased because of the increased likelihood of co-occurring warm conditions. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate change adaptation.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. It is therefore challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes and may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. These findings are important because they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the proteins that form the channel pore or the Ca2+ sensor impair the function of this channel. Here, we identify mutations in two components of the CRAC channel that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy, but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Furthermore, our data suggest that the CRAC channel is a therapeutic target in the treatment of immune dysfunction in patients with autoimmune diseases. Finally, our data highlight the importance of the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 in the regulation of the CRAC channel. These findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the CRAC channel and its role in health and disease. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to study the spreading of aggregates in the brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, demonstrating that they are not cleared by the immune system. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous, and that this spreading can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis in the spreading neurons. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of spreading in other diseases, including prion diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are still poorly understood. Here, we identified a protein, MTX, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by inhibiting the activity of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit the generation of LTB4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. These findings may help to understand the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats and provide a potential target for the development of antiviral drugs. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is required for the conversion of serine to glycine and the transfer of a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we identify a pyrazolopyran scaffold that inhibits plant SHMT, and use this scaffold to identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2. We show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this is due to defective glycine import in these cell lines. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT that may be useful in cancer therapy. It also provides a rationale for the use of glycine as a therapeutic target in cancer. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable model of inclusion body formation may be relevant to other neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cold atoms are a versatile platform for exploring fundamental physics and for applications in quantum technologies. The ability to control the interactions between atoms is a key enabling technology for many applications. In this work, we present a 2D photonic crystal system for controlling the interactions between cold atoms. The device is fabricated from a silicon nitride layer, which is a promising platform for future applications in quantum technologies. The device can be used to control the interactions between cold atoms in a 2D array, and can be used to study the physics of many-body systems. The device can also be used to study the physics of light–matter interactions, and can be used for applications in quantum technologies.

The origin of angiosperms is one of the most important and debated topics in plant evolution. The study of the very early angiosperms, such as Montsechia, is of great importance because it opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but the evolutionary history of many viruses is unknown because of the difficulty of obtaining genetic sequences from ancient samples. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes, which are from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also provides a unique resource for future studies of the evolution of B19V and other viruses. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. These changes are due to a combination of natural processes and human-induced climate change. The rate of rise is a key indicator of the magnitude of the problem and the effectiveness of adaptation and mitigation efforts.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This picture provides insight into the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state, which is key to understanding the observed specificity of the natural substrate indole. The results also highlight the importance of the crystallographic environment in determining the chemical outcome of the reaction. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of enzyme intermediates, and the results provide a detailed picture of the reaction pathway in a key enzyme mechanism. This work also provides a demonstration of the power of the integrated application of solid-state NMR, X-ray crystallography, and first-principles computational chemistry. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe, often fatal, pneumonia caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV). There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. These data support the conduct of a clinical trial of remdesivir in MERS patients. Remdesivir may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This is an important step forward in the development of antiviral treatments for MERS and other coronaviruses. The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health and development. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by a host to its symbiotic bacteria is a mechanism used to regulate the activities of the microbiota and the health of the host. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbiont bacteria. This glycan provision and catabolism is required for the host to maintain a healthy symbiotic relationship with its bacteria. This glycan provision and catabolism is also required for the host to maintain a healthy symbiotic relationship with its bacteria. Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, and the consequences of suspension are severe. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this can be sustained over time. Moreover, this intervention bolstered the respect that at-risk students have for teachers. These findings have implications for the design of scalable interventions to reduce suspension rates. They also have implications for the design of school discipline policies, which have been shown to have a large impact on the quality of teacher–student relationships.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to mutagenesis and even cell death. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop), which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that has caused more than 800 deaths since its emergence in 2012. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that block sequential proteolysis of the spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Our findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These results also provide insights into the mechanisms of SARS-CoV infection, which is the prototype for the severe pneumonia caused by coronaviruses.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the majority of the population have a significant impact on the environment and on population health. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering environment can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a simple and effective way to make a difference to the environment and to population health. The results also suggest that it is possible to nudge people’s choices in a more sustainable direction. This is an important finding that can be used to inform future research and policy.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell and its extracellular environment. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a proof of principle for the application of AI-ETD for the analysis of intact glycopeptides. This technique may be applicable to other systems, including cancer cells, and may be useful for the analysis of other types of proteomics data. It is also a promising approach for the analysis of glycan-encoded information in the cell surface glycoproteome.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail are not well understood. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. However, vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We hope that this paper will help inform the public debate about the merits of vote-by-mail.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of vaccines and therapeutics. However, the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is important for immune evasion and may be a target for future vaccine development. These results provide insights into the molecular basis of the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxia-induced edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

The analysis of large datasets has led to a new challenge: How do we assess the strength of associations in the presence of many potential associations? This paper describes a new approach to selective inference that is appropriate for the era of big data. The approach is based on the idea that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We illustrate the new approach in the context of forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The new approach is more powerful and more efficient than existing methods. It is also more transparent, in that it makes explicit the assumptions that are being made about the data.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the repair of ischemic tissues. However, the generation of ECs is difficult, and the number of factors that induce ECs is still unknown. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces the generation of endothelial cells from fibroblasts. In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, ETV2 induces expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also provides a promising therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders. (Show more)

The role of ligand-activated RTKs in development and disease has been extensively studied. However, the physiological function of the “orphan” RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has remained elusive. Here, we show that zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands for Alk and Ltk display a severe defect in iridophore patterning. We further demonstrate that augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in the eye and the body. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the function of augmentor ligands and their role in the development of the zebrafish body coloration. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of augmentor ligands in human diseases. (Show more)

β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D), but the molecular mechanisms remain to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function, and its deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of STING in the pathogenesis of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral RNA packaging and may help in the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including hemodynamic environment. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate that YAP/TAZ is activated by disturbed flow and plays a critical role in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural and human landscape for millennia. However, in recent decades, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially. Climate change has likely contributed to some of the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires in the United States. Our results show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occur in areas where fuel moisture is higher, thereby helping to expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to reduce the risk of human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies and urban geography. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. We believe that our work will be of interest to urban geographers, urban sociologists, and urban economists. We hope that our work will also inspire others to use computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The study also provides a new target for the development of insect repellent. (Show more)

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the viral infection within the host may play an important role. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within an individual, the rate of viral production, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can help to inform the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered to be a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work also highlights the importance of nutrient cycling in the context of climate change and coral reef degradation. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In this study, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can alter the composition of the microbiome and trigger a regenerative response that promotes tumor growth. We also identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and for developing strategies to control tumor growth. They also provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between host and microbial homeostasis and regeneration. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are estrogen receptor-positive, a small proportion of patients do not respond to endocrine therapy. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. Here we show that the onset of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which, in turn, is linked to stratospheric ozone depletion. This provides a unique link between the timing of the onset of deglaciation and the recovery of the stratospheric ozone layer.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in environmental planning and policy. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. This highlights the critical role of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to improve fishery management and protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is still a major concern due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve high-energy aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of safe and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The work also provides a new perspective for the development of safe and high-energy aqueous batteries. The work is expected to be of great significance for the development of safe and high-energy aqueous batteries.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway and is triggered by physical lesion of the dendrite. This form of regeneration is remarkably independent of the MAPK pathway and is reminiscent of a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that the MAPK pathway is not the only pathway that controls the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. We also find that this form of regeneration is triggered by a reduction in neuronal activity and is enhanced by elevating cAMP levels. These findings may lead to the development of new therapies for the treatment of neurological disorders. (Show more)

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. It is also a process that is highly variable across the genome. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable, with some regions of the genome showing little recombination, whereas others show intense recombination. These regions are interspersed with regions of low recombination. We also find that recombination is more likely to terminate in exons than in introns. These results provide a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant and may provide insights into the evolution of recombination in other organisms. This work also provides a resource for studying recombination in a wild plant population.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of different regions fluctuates over time. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a number of topographically organized networks, which are thought to reflect functional properties of the brain. However, the validity of this approach has not been fully established. Here, we show that the dominant network in the resting brain is topographically similar to the default mode network, and that this network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern in Parkinson’s disease. Furthermore, we show that this network is functionally related to the expression of metabolic activity in the brain. These results provide a direct link between the organization of the brain at rest and its functional properties. They also provide a framework for the study of the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA that regulates translation. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-mRNA is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. These results define a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that the NAD-cap could regulate translation of specific classes of mRNA. This work provides a better understanding of the regulation of gene expression in yeast and may have implications for understanding the function of NAD+ in eukaryotes. The study of epigenetic changes in diabetes is of great interest because of the potential for epigenetic mechanisms to be involved in the development of diabetes complications. In this study, we show that epigenetic changes in DNA methylation at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes of people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), which was the landmark study in the field of diabetes. These epigenetic changes are associated with glycemia, and may be involved in the development of diabetes complications.

The role of the tumor suppressor gene Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may be a previously unidentified target in the management of this disease.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for the development of a distinctive aroma, but the biosynthetic pathways for these compounds are unknown. Here we identify a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of 2-substituted tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid substrates into a mixture of the corresponding 2-substituted oxime, nitro, and nitrile volatiles. This pathway is distinct from other known flavin-dependent monooxygenases in plants and provides a major step forward in understanding and ultimately improving tomato flavor quality. This work also provides a model for the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous volatiles in plants. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in isolation from other factors that may influence ecosystem performance. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of global warming in addition to biodiversity loss when assessing the impacts of human activities on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to record from a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for the formation of place memories, are organized in a distinct manner from other neurons. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC neurons in vivo and will be useful for understanding the functional roles of MEC in navigation. This work also provides a platform for future studies of the neural basis of memory and consciousness.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra, the classic site of degeneration in Parkinson’s disease, receive input from a previously unknown subsystem of the nigral system, the striatonigral system. This subsystem is formed by striosomal neurons that project to the striosome, a subcompartment of the striatum, and from there to ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent cell bodies in the ventral midbrain. We suggest that this subsystem is critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are often asked, “Do you and [person] click?” This question is difficult to answer because it is subjective. We propose that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and objective signal of whether two minds “click.” We show that this signal is used by others to assess the quality of the connection between two people. We also show that this signal is used by the people themselves to assess their own connection to others. Finally, we show that this signal is used by people to assess the quality of their connection to others. Together, these findings suggest that response time is a robust and honest signal of connection.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. These findings provide insights into the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the order in which information is presented. This makes it suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. These findings are important for the development of plant biotechnology. (Show more)

Eutrophication of lakes and coastal waters is a global problem, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient loading from surrounding watersheds. However, the role of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient inputs is poorly understood. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. Our results reveal that small watersheds are a significant source of coastal nutrients, and that their plumes become trapped in nearshore areas, where they can overlap. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This is especially important in large water bodies, where the total nutrient loads from small watersheds are small but the number of watersheds is large. Our findings have important implications for coastal water quality management.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding is relevant to the study of the dynamics of complex networks, where the rare combinations of states may correspond to the emergence of new functions. Our results also provide a mechanism for the emergence of a nonstationary steady state in a system that is driven by a single environmental forcing. This mechanism may be relevant to the study of the dynamics of complex networks in a variety of contexts.

Here we show that these antibodies can change the intrinsic properties of the cortex, which in turn can alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system history. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was associated with an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of abrupt climate change and the potential for future climate change.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. Despite its widespread adoption, the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation has not been quantified. We use a unique dataset of oil palm plantations in Indonesia to show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation. However, certification had no causal impact on deforestation in peatlands or active fire detection. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet delivering on its promise to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential drug target for diseases related to the exocyst complex. The genetic basis of sex in vertebrates is a key component of the evolution of sexual dimorphism and sexual selection. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics may be a general consequence of polygenic sex determination. This modularity may be important for understanding the evolution of sexual dimorphism and sexual selection. It may also be important for understanding the effects of sex determination on the evolution of sexual conflict.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species. These species are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A and can damage the retina. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoid lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that Fe levels impact the retina and that Fe levels are important in the oxidation and degradation of a retinal pigment epithelium-specific bisretinoid. These findings have implications for the retina and for the development of therapeutics for retinal diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predator specialization is a key component of the structure of many food webs, but the evolutionary mechanisms that drive this process are not well understood. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved to be highly specialized on a single prey type, and that these specializations are linked to the evolution of their tentacles and nematocysts. Our results suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a case study of how morphological changes can be localized in separate structures dedicated to prey capture.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the emergence of the distinctive features of the modern human hand are poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive hand features of Neandertals and modern humans arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also highlights the importance of the fossil record in understanding the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon unit pool, which is essential for cell growth. In mammals, SHMT1 is cytosolic, whereas SHMT2 is mitochondrial. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in mice results in the death of the organism. We also show that dual SHMT inhibitors are effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. Finally, we show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results provide a foundation for the development of small-molecule dual SHMT inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for cancer. They also provide a metabolic target for the treatment of lymphoma. The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A, and thus can reduce vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which can increase vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is the first study to our knowledge to use causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of modern agriculture, but at the cost of soil compaction. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a shift in the spatial distribution of compaction risk, with a higher risk of subsoil compaction in the modern world. This shift is due to the increase in mean tractor size, which has led to the propagation of compaction into deeper soil layers. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. We hypothesize that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the largest sauropods had a higher propensity to roam in search of food.
